Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black; triangular pattern in added white above band of white lozenges with added red centres between pairs of white bands; below, part of lotus flower and tendril in white and red; exterior: painted decoration consisting of female figure to right (long black tresses, black chiton, red himation with staggered double dot decoration on sleeve and hand in outline remaining); on either side of figure, possible spiked rosettes as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Although Lemos does not describe this sherd, it should belong to the Group with the Filling Ornament. The features typical for this group of vessels are the milky white slip and the use of filling ornament, which is found only in this group of sherds of the Grand Style. The presence of filling ornament also suggests that the vases were mostly likely the earliest in that style. The male figures portrayed on vases from this group are perhaps the most expertly depicted and may all have been done by the same hand. Finally, the attempt at creating some perspective is rather clumsy.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0837) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
